body: The only way I can think of now is do to a COUNT() query so you know if you need to UPDATE or INSERT. Is that a good approach to fix this bug?
Is it reproducible in a unit test (it should be)?
Issuing `count()` doesn't sound right to me. It hurts both performance (cache is all about it, right) and atomicity.

I haven't looked at the unit tests.

The only way to fix it without impacting performance (so no COUNT(*) query) seems to be to set `PDO::MYSQL_ATTR_FOUND_ROWS => true` by default then, but all databases use the same `yii\db\Connection` class, so that doesn't seem like it is the right place. Also, it might not be the behaviour what is expected. It seems okay to expect that update() returns the number of changed rows, it just seems wrong to expect that the number of changed rows means the update query was succesful.

@samdark I've tried running the tests locally, and it seems they are already failing.

```sh
$ phpunit -v tests/framework/caching/DbCacheTest.php
Applying compatibility patch for PHPUnit 6...
PHPUnit 4.8.34 by Sebastian Bergmann and contributors.

Runtime:	PHP 7.0.14
Configuration:	/project/phpunit.xml.dist

..F...............

Time: 9.68 seconds, Memory: 6.00MB

There was 1 failure:

1) yiiunit\framework\caching\DbCacheTest::testSet
Failed asserting that false is true.

/project/tests/framework/caching/CacheTestCase.php:89
/project/vendor/phpunit/phpunit/phpunit:52

FAILURES!
Tests: 18, Assertions: 52, Failures: 1.
```

The CacheTestCase on line 89, in `testSet()`, does this:
```php
        $this->assertTrue($cache->set('string_test', 'string_test'));
```
I guess this fails because on line 77, in  the `prepare()`, it does this:
```php
        $cache->set('string_test', 'string_test');
```

I assume if this happens in the same second, the test on line 89 fails.

Are you sure that travis is running also database tests?

issue.title: Fixes #14660: fixed synchronous DbCache::set() with the same key
